cards.alt: Mike Jones - AI Implementation Expert and LLM Integration Specialist

cards.text: Building better systems for 29 years—from Xbox launch teams to AI implementation

cards.markdown:
Before I ever touched code, I was optimizing systems. As a college warehouse manager, I redesigned workflows to move product faster. At Microsoft, I created the VINCE instrumentation tool that made invisible player data visible—opening new careers and eventually evolving into Halo's Kill Cam feature.

Every company since has followed the same pattern: I hear problems others are having, identify the gaps in existing systems, and create something that fills that gap. It's not about technology for its own sake—it's people-centered. When teams thrive, organizations thrive. Building better systems creates opportunities for everyone.

cards.text: From Political Science to Xbox: An Accidental Path to Tech

cards.markdown:
Between ages 10 and 14, I dreamed of making video games. By college, I'd pivoted to political science—not because I wanted to run for office, but because I was fascinated by **systems**: how projects move through processes, how laws pass, how society is governed.

Then came the tech pivot. My roommate was studying for Microsoft networking certifications, and I realized I understood the material better than he did. I could see how processes and projects worked together. Around the same time, I hacked the college network so we could play multiplayer Doom (1990-91).

After graduation, I worked at Aviation Supplies & Academics doing tech support and QA for flight simulator software. I loved it, but realized my passion was software, not politics. I enrolled at the University of Washington for computer science, met someone at Microsoft Games, and within six weeks landed my dream job at Microsoft Games Organization in 1999.

Over 29 years, I've worked across gaming, entertainment, media, and tech—always focused on creating systems that help people thrive.

**Microsoft (1999-2007):** Xbox & Xbox 360 launch teams, contributed to 6 AAA titles. Created VINCE instrumentation tool (Xbox SDK patent) that evolved into Halo's Kill Cam feature.

**Director Roles (2008-2021):** Led PMO and production teams at Kabam (hypergrowth gaming), Livescribe (digital pen systems), Kinoo (AR communication platform - 10 awards including CES Innovation Award).

**8 Circuit Studios (2022-2024):** Co-founder of Web3 gaming company building "proto-metaverse" with player ownership and creator royalties.

**Metrics:** Managed teams of `50-120+` people, budgets `$4M-$12M+`. Achieved `80%` improvement in delivery predictability, `3x` operational efficiency gains.

cards.text: The AI Transition: From Systems Guy to AI Builder

cards.markdown:
I started using AI seriously about 2.5 years ago. The ChatGPT 2025 Year in Review report showed I was in the top 1% of users and top 3% for conversation volume.

Why did AI click for me? As a systems thinker, I've always seen connections others couldn't follow. AI gave me structure to create "straight lines" so others could see what I saw. It enabled Resilient Tomorrow, where AI helped me organize my thoughts into meaningful conversations that resonated with thousands of readers.

I quickly mastered prompting, but realized the real key is **CONTEXT**—give AI the right context and it can help you find answers you didn't know you were looking for. Once I saw AI could help me code, build prototypes, create things I wanted to exist in the world—there was no stopping it.

Now I'm not just using AI systems, I'm **building** them: AI Memory System for persistent context across conversations, Local LLM infrastructure for privacy and sovereignty, and AI-Augmented Process Design (AAPD) methodology for clients who need to untangle complex workflows.

Today I'm working on parallel projects that all implement the same vision—building systems that reduce dependency and give people more agency.

**Velocity Partners:** AI-augmented PMO consulting for gaming, entertainment, and media companies (50-1500 person teams). AAPD methodology, PM Drowning framework, fractional PMO services. Making work flow.

**NeighborhoodShare:** Tool-sharing platform using AI to categorize items and build hyperlocal community through mutual aid. Started with an angle grinder story—solving problems with resources already around us.

**AI Memory System:** Personal knowledge management infrastructure that maintains context across AI conversations and platforms. JSONL format, cross-AI compatible (Claude, ChatGPT, OpenWebUI). Solves the context loss problem.

**Local LLM Infrastructure:** Self-hosted AI running on Mac Mini (Ollama + OpenWebUI). Privacy, sovereignty, offline capability. AI built to work for me, not on me.

**Resilient Tomorrow:** Substack publication on community resilience and building parallel systems. 7 Pillars framework. Top articles: 989 likes, 230 restacks. Includes Offramp Assistant GPT and Community Defense Playbook.

All of these projects implement the **7 Pillars** framework from Resilient Tomorrow—building parallel systems that reduce dependency on fragile centralized infrastructure.

NeighborhoodShare implements Pillar 3 (Access > Money) and Pillar 7 (Hyperlocal Community). AI Memory and Local LLM implement Pillar 4 (Knowledge Stewardship) and Pillar 5 (Communication Independence). Resilient Tomorrow is the thesis tying it all together.

The core philosophy: **"You don't burn the old system down until the new one can carry weight."** I'm building in parallel while still living in the world as it is. Not about purity—it's about direction.

Creating efficiency and better systems has been my through-line since college warehouse days. But it's always been people-centered—hearing team problems, filling gaps, creating opportunities for others to grow.

It's not about individual mastery, it's about shared capability. Not about purity, it's about direction. I build systems that help people thrive.
